segments.text: This is Marilee Nolan interviewing Frank Galvan.
Where is your mic?
You don't need one.
It's right there.
Very sensitive.
All right, if you could begin with your name and where you were born, your age.
My name is Frank J. Galvan, Jr.
I was born in Santa Barbara, Chihuahua, Mexico on February the 8th, the 11th, 1908.
And I am 65 years of age.
And when did you leave Mexico?
We left Mexico sometime in the middle of 1913.
We left Mexico from our point of origin, which was Santa Barbara, Chihuahua, Mexico.
My father had been a government, federal employee in the city of Santa Barbara.
and at the outbreak of the revolution he was branded as a uh things got a little dangerous for him so he fled from santa barbara to chihuahua incognito and from chihuahua it is
believe that he left as far from Mexico as possible and I am under the impression that he finally reached his destination somewhere in Canada.
Go on.
Did you and your family go with him then?
No.
He left the family all in the city of the town of Santa Barbara, Chihuahua.
And we had a home, a two-story home.
And while he was away for some, it looked to me like it was years,
We were penniless, poverty-stricken, and had to exist by converting the upper story of the house into a rooming house.
There was a yard in the center of the house and a second yard
to the rear that used to be called two patios.
One for the servants and the other ones for the members of the household.
Anyway, we managed to exist during the revolution by selling hierba buena.
We used to, there was a farm nearby
